text:
- Uh, welcome to Jordan.
- Hi, Natasha.
Nice to meet you.

I'm very happy
to have you here.

And we've got loads
of different questions for you
from all around the world.

- Are you ready?
- Yes.

Well, what inspired you guys
to make the first live show

of "Everyday Life" album
in Jordan?
Much love.

- So sweet.
- Natasha: Yeah.

I think it's exciting for us
to be here in Jordan

because we haven't
been here before,
first and foremost.

We've spent a long time
traveling the world

and I think
it's important to us

to try and reach
as many people
as possible

and go and see our fans
wherever they are.
So, I think the decision

to come here was
partly based on that.
Well, there's a sort of...

easy route
that you can keep taking
if you're a big touring band.
And it goes to amazing places,

but it also avoids a lot
of amazing places.

For reasons of mechanics
normally and budgets.

So there's a lot of places
we'd like to play that we--

it's too expensive
to make it all work.

So I think given that we're not
touring this record,

we thought where is the place
in the middle

of the biggest region where
we never really get to play in.
That happens to be in Jordan.
It also feels good for us

to come bang into the middle
of the Middle East

'cause bands like us
don't tend to come here.

My question is
what about the process to decide

which songs belong to Sunset
or Sunrise.
I think when we decided

to kind of make it
into a double album,

I think it was important when
we were doing the track listing

that each of those two sections
felt well-balanced.

So you could kind of listen
to one or the other

or you could listen
to the whole thing at once.

The songs on Sunrise
are a little bit more
about tricky situations.

And the songs on Sunset
are a little bit more

about maybe how we might
navigate those situations.

- Okay.
- So, there is a sort of ying
and yang to them as well.

Hello, Coldplay.
 This is Harsh from India.

Why did you write in
the year 1919

on the posters
of "Everyday Life"?

Is it related
to some songs in it?
Namaste.
Uh, well, it was related

to the fact that the album cover
is from an old photograph

of my great grandfather
and his band

with my two great uncles in it
and some other people.
And it was from about 1919.
And it's also related

to the fact we wanted the album
to speak of generations

as well as people
around the world.

So not, you know, people we
wanted to reach across time

as well, I think.
( laughs )
Not to be too cheesy.

- Just another regular album.
- Exactly.

- Reaching across time.
- Reaching the centuries, yeah.

Why did you guys decide
to record "Everyday Life"
as a double album

and what are the differences
between Sunrise and Sunset,

musically and lyrically,
if any at all?
We were in Paris in the summer.

Guy said, "Can we just listen
to everything that we've got?"

And I said, "Okay."
And he said,

"And can you put it
in some kind of order?"

And he gave me
about three minutes to do it.
So I went into the other room

and did it and I thought "Well,
this is probably too long,

but this is all the songs
that I like."
And we listened through

and it wasn't actually that long
to listen to.

And at the end Guy just said,
"Yeah, that's good."

Which I was not expecting
at all.

So then we--
the four of us talked a bit

and with Phil and we said,
"Well, it's a lot of tracks,

but if we split it
into Sunrise and Sunset--"

It was so forbidden for us
to do a double album ever.

And the whole spirit
of the band right now

is just to abandon
any sense of fear.

We just thought,
"Okay, ( bleep ) it and--"

Sorry.
Can I swear?

Am I not allowed
to swear on YouTube?

- Woman: What'd you say?
- Doesn't matter.

Why did you decide
to use explicit language

on your songs
for the first time?

Okay.
Yeah.

Our band works in a
very beautiful way.
Um, like, um, a series of doors
that a song has to get through.

If an idea arrives
in the middle of the night,

I might say, "Jonny, look,
this idea arrived.
What do you think?"

And he might say,
"Yeah, I'll play on that."

And then it gets built
to level two.

And then we might say to Guy,
"What do you think?"
And he might say yes or no

and it might get
through the Guy door.

And then it gets built
to level three.

The hardest door of all
is level four,
which is Will's door.

'cause Will is the anchor
of our band

and he's also the sort of
emotional esthete.

- Is that the right word?
- Yeah.

- Yeah. Thank you.
- That's lovely. Thank you.

So, if he doesn't think
something resonates
or is not genuine,

it won't be allowed
through his door.

So I have to put them
in the dust bin.
Never before has a song--
Where there's been--

'cause some of the swearing
just happens within a song.

And I'll do it, but Will has
always just shut the door

and be like, "No, bring it back
when it's, you know, clean."

- ( all laugh )
- Which is very much how he--

- It's my only consideration.
- This whole crew.

- ( all laugh )
- Is this clean?

- Is this clean?
- Clean this up.

This time there were
a couple of songs

where there was some
swearing in.

And he didn't say anything
so I thought, "Okay.
I guess that means it's okay."

- And he--
- The door is open.

- Briefly.
- ( laughs )

He's never said anything
about it.

- So I'd like to know--
- No.

Either he wasn't
paying attention

or he just felt like,
"Okay, that's real."

No, I think, generally,
I think that's right.
The idea of--

Sometimes there is--
there are more elegant ways

of... you know,
of saying something--

while the swear words are
extremely useful at times,

aren't they?
And necessary.

But if you overuse them,
it lessens their impact.

The swear jar is empty,
you know.

You've been--
You've saved it all up.

And I think I'm grateful
that you've used them
on these songs.

Thank you.
Thank you for your permission.

- Got another question for you,
Guy.
- Okay.

- I am now.
- ( laughs )
That was the next question.

I wanted to know how many songs
in "Everyday Life"

are actually old songs or demos
reworked for this new album.
As with any record,

there are things
that ended up on this album

that have sort of ancestors
and parents

or grandparents
of songs in the--
from previous things.

Sometimes there's a bit
of music or a riff

or a chord progression
or a lyric or even a title

that doesn't find its place
on an old record

but we know
that it's of worth.

So it's something
that we kind of sit on

and we just think like
you know, like all things,

everything has
its right time.

We've got a question
from John.

- And the question says,
  "What type of world events--
- Where is John from, though?

- Oh, it doesn't say,
unfortunately.
- Okay.

- So let's imagine.
- Let's imagine.

- What's he look like, Jonny?
- John--

- Tall, handsome.
- What does John look like?

- You're describing yourself.
- Like all Johns.

- Bearded.
- Okay.

- He sat right next to you.
- Okay.

All right,
I'll address it to you.
So, he asks.

This very
handsome-looking John.

"What type of world events
influenced the making
of 'Everyday Life'?"
Oh, that's a wonderful question.

The answer is everything
and anything.

And, uh, some of the songs are
very inside looking out

and some are very outside
looking in.

If that makes any sense,
which it doesn't really.

Some are my
or our personal experience.

Others are our personal view
of things that we see happening.

And some songs are
putting yourself
in other people's shoes.

At the moment it seems
that there's a whole portion

of the world that is fed
this kind of,

um, terrified image
of otherness.

Of, you know, these people are
different to you.

These people are
to be scared of.
And, um, I think that

in our own small way,
we are really rallying
against that viewpoint.

Every human is precious
and every human has magic.

- Okay.
- But some of it's still about,
you know,
girls and stuff.

Gabby asks Will, "How do you
guys think that 'Everyday Life'
can help change the world?"

How can it
change the world?
That's a--

I like to--
Well, hang on,
let me think about this.

Come on,
it's an easy question.

For us, the opportunity
that we have

to speak to people
or people to listen
to our music,

we want to try
and use that to--

to promote the things that we--
that we really believe in.

Try to spread positivity
and sense of togetherness.

We feel like
we're extremely lucky,

and we want to use
that opportunity
to try and--

to try and do something nice
for people,

to provide a kind of sense
of community.

The strongest message
that we have is within
the fabric of the band.

We're living proof
that collaboration can work
despite your differences.

Next question is from Liz...
for Jonny.

"Can we expect
an 'Everyday Life' tour?"
Uh... no.
That was an easy one.

We have a tour starting today,
but it finishes on Monday.
Yes, it's three days long.
Two day tour.

Been very lucky that we get
to do this thing on YouTube,
which is awesome.
It's a one world tour in one go.

But also we're letting our
tour appetite just fill up

- in the meantime.
- Okay.
Yeah, we're excited.
Who are you speaking for?

- For everybody.
- Okay.

It's the first album of ours
that we're on the cover.

- That's very interesting.
- Yeah.

- And maybe the last.
- ( laughs )
Let's hope not.
( overlapping chatter )
Right-- Right on cue.

But I wanna address this
because I always say
that it's our last album.

And what I mean by that is
we put everything into it.

Like if you asked a marathon
runner at the end of the race,

like, "What time are you gonna
race tomorrow?"

They'd be like,
"Oh, just give me a minute."

- That's the same.
- Okay.

But I didn't say that
about this one.

- I know.
- ( all laugh )

- It's not our last album.
- Some people are saying it.

We'd like to know
what was your favorite part
of making "Everyday Life"?

- Los queremos, chicos. 
- Whoo!
It's been really wonderful

the way we've been recording
on this particular session.

This album has been intense
periods of time

together
in interesting locations.

The one
that sticks out for me

and where the, I think,
the album first started
to really take roots

was in a barn
on top of a hill in Tuscany.

Just a feeling of we were all
living in a house together,

eating meals together,
going for walk.

And, you know, it was
just a really special time

and I remember it very fondly
and I think a lot

of great music came out
of the two weeks
we were there.
Hi, this is Eyad from Palestine.

What song would you say is
the most personal song for you
in the "Everyday Life" album?

That's a great question.
The truth is all of them.

Nothing really makes it through
if it isn't personal.
Got a question from Tanya.

She says,
"What is your favorite bit,

song lyric, riff, beat,
anything off of the album?"
Love the horns in "Arabesque."

- That's what I was gonna say.
- Oh.

I'll just think
of something else now.
The joy of going first.

Probably the opening
of the whole thing.

On top of this piano piece
Dav played this other line
and I thought it was amazing.
And he did this string demo

and I went down to listen to it
and we then scrapped

what was then the opening song
of this record

and put that on instead,
"Sunrise."

That's probably my favorite also
'cause I'm not on it very much.

In fact, none of us are on it,
actually.

- So that's why.
- ( all laugh )
That's why you like it.

Natasha: I don't know
what to say to that.
But I love all of it.

I'm enjoying playing a song
called "Champion of the World"

at the moment
because it's very--

it feels just like a kind
of real band performance.

And so, you know,
for that reason that it's--

it feels good to me.
There's a good--

There's a good band energy
in that song.

At the moment my favorite
bit of music

is the second chorus
of "Everyday Life."

There's a tone
of Chris's voice

that he managed to get
on that recording

and then there's a bit
where there's a few
more voices joining.

- Which voices, Will?
- Well, some-- some bloke.

- It's your voice.
- And-- It's my voice, but it's
also my wife's voice.

And it's also
your wife's voice.
And that is great for her

because she's
an amazing singer.
And she loves singing.

And it was such
a lovely day

when she came into sing
on that song.

And so that definitely resonates
really--

I have a voice memo,
in fact, on my phone

of when we were all
singing it together.

And I sometimes just send
that to her

as a reminder
of how great she is.

So, that's definitely the one
that I remember most.
Did we pay her properly?

Chris, I know you had planned
to perform a song

for the fans that--
And they voted for it.

But I understand
that you're having
a bit of a problem
with your vocals.
I'm not gonna sing today.

Please, can I wait
until Saturday?

I'm asking for an extension
of my homework.

We'll do it--
We'll do it in a few days.

When I was at school,
I used to have to ask

for extensions
on doing essays.

And I'd have to go
to this teacher's house

and I would be so nervous
and terrified

and he was always scary
about it.

And that's
what I'm asking for today.

Please, can I have
just a few more days

and I will hand
the song in live.
We'll collectively do it.

So, hopefully you'll be
doing it in a few days.

Yeah, what was the song?
"Sparks" or something like that.

- Yeah.
- "Viva la Vida."

- We'll do both of them.
- ( laughs )

Well, it was lovely
to have all of you.

- Thank you so much.
- Thank you.

- Thank you, everybody, watching
and sent questions.
- Yeah, thank you.
